awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Biomimetic Engineered Space Technology Platform
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to provide cost reduction and time-saving for researchers in academia and industry in designing studies to be conducted in an extraterrestrial gravity environment (e.g., low-Earth orbit, Martian gravity, or lunar gravity).  Currently, pharmaceutical companies and researchers in academia (biology, chemistry, bioengineering fields) need a platform for producing reliable and replicable data in simulated extraterrestrial gravity before sending the experiments to the International Space Station (ISS). While the experimental set-up size limitation at ISS requires diligent optimization of independent variables in experiments, the high flight cost to the ISS and one-time opportunity in running experiments there necessitates absolute success in experimental execution with already tested experimental parameters. This technology provides time and cost effective solutions to overcome the shortcomings of experimental preparations prior to launching to the ISS. This core technology also has potential applications for improving outcomes for elderly populations and patients with prolonged immobility. The creation of knowledge in this area can benefit drug development and rehabilitation efforts aimed at revitalizing deteriorating tissues caused by prolonged immobilization.

This I-Corps project simulates extraterrestrial gravity to study the gravity-sensitive mechanisms of organic and inorganic materials, cells, tissues, and organs in a three-dimensional dynamic environment. The key technical innovations underpinning the platform involve being able to mimic a varying gravitational environment on Earth and monitor the gravitational forces in situ.  It necessary, the technology will also be able to modulate conditions while providing realistic culturing and processing environments for cells, proteins, and materials. The platform uses an innovative technique to reach a pre-defined gravitational state in 60-90 seconds by  independently rotating two computer-controlled axes.  The data acquisition chip placed in the device collects and plots the gravity data for a user to track/observe the gravitational force.  Another technical innovation of this I-Corps project is that various mechanical strains can be applied to the sample of interest in a temperature, light, and humidity-controlled environment to study the samples in realistic conditions under a pre-defined, simulated gravitational state.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our technology is an altered gravity (microgravity, Martian gravity, Lunar gravity, etc.) simulator that can simulate any partial gravity conditions on Earth while conducting the experiments with different complexity (from two-dimensional (2D) monolayer to 3D tissue matrix to organ culture) under relevant physical and chemical conditions.  

The major goal of this project circulating our technology are twofolds: 1) to understand whether there is enough demand for microgravity and other gravity simulators offering advanced and controlled culturing environments 2) to identify the potential customer segments and ecosystem related our technology and further to understand the pain experienced by potential customer segments.

Upon completion of the award, we lidentified the customers’ problems are different for each sub-groups, the proposed technology will address the customers’ pain in a very cost-effective way. For ground-based researchers’ biggest pains are 1) mimicking and real-time tracking the altered gravity conditions on Earth accurately, 2) being able to reach the desired gravity almost instantly before samples acclimate the changing conditions, 3) being able to work with 3D tissues and organs, 4) being able to modulate culturing samples mechanically and chemically in simulated altered gravity conditions. For space-based researchers, the biggest challenges are associated with the cost of sending experiments to ISS and limited cargo space. Sending a shoebox-size experimental set-up to ISS costs around $1 million including preparation of the experiments and equipment, shuttle fee, and astronauts’ time at ISS.

During our interviews, the space-based scientists further emphasized that ultimately, they run their experiments in a real ISS environment but before launching the experiments to ISS, they need to conduct preliminary experiments on Earth using simulated microgravity platforms. The cost of a failure is too steep for them thus they need to narrow down the independent variables numbers and identify the most important independent variables to be tested at ISS due to a limited number of samples that can fit small cargo space (14x10x7 in3).  

In sum, almost all the interviewees around the globe agreed that there is a huge unmet need for an accurate, cost-effective, and reliable altered gravity simulator accommodating living samples with various complexity from 2D to organ under physiologically relevant conditions. Our technology will be able to address these unmet needs with its unique features explained below.  

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/21/2023
Modified by: Eda Yildirim-Ayan
